story:
Our Story:

In 2015, we launched the Danbury Chamber Music Intensive (CMI), a week-long summer program housed at the Danbury Music Centre, an 80 year-old community music organization. The program invites emerging professional musicians to Danbury to teach and perform with local aspiring musicians through chamber music rehearsals, master classes, and performances. CMI now annually provides a unique and intense chamber music experience to local musicians, both children and adults, who may not have ever been exposed to chamber music.

In conceiving of CMI, we decided one core aspect of this program would be a concert series the artists perform. We planned four free community concerts throughout the week of CMI because we wanted to provide CMI program participants and the community at large with the opportunity to hear high-quality chamber music performance alongside the daily educational activities the participants engaged in. One of concerts the first year was a new music concert called "Charles Ives and His Living Legacy" featuring the music of Ives alongside living composers. It was a hit! Our community loved the idea that their hometown hero spurring an entire tradition of American concert music and also meeting the composers who were carrying on that tradition. In 2016, we expanded our series from 4 concerts to 6, programmed more contemporary music, and had our first ever composer-in-residence, Robert Beaser. Today, we are beyond excited to announce that after consulting with the Charles Ives Society, our concert series is now officially the Charles Ives Concert Series, which is committed to exploring the legacy of Ives and his music. 

In the broadest of terms, our goal is to celebrate Ives' legacy by transforming the musical life of the Danbury area. With your help, we can begin to make Danbury a place known not just for its hometown composer, but for its numerous performances of today's American composers powered by a concert series that regularly features dynamic and unique emerging artists performing their works alongside the music of Ives and music that transcends the traditional boundaries of classical music to incorporate other styles - an "Ivesian" tradition.  In just two years, we've performed and/or premiered the work of almost 30 American composers and are poised to hit 40 by the end of the year. We can envision a future in Danbury where this series is not only a hub for American music, but one in which this series is a Danbury area cultural icon. 

We realize this is a long road, but it's one we're excited about traveling and your contributions to this launch fund allow us to chart a course that gets us to our destination.

We're trying to raise $5,000 to transform Danbury's musical life. Here's how we get started: 

1. Your support ensures a successful inaugural season and many more.  

We have a really exciting lineup planned for our first-ever season, but we need your support. Your contributions go toward fees for our outstanding artists, marketing and promotion, instrument rental, and recording. Your support also enables us to keep our concerts FREE!!

Here's what we've got on tap for this summer:

August 6th: Folk Music in the Age of Ives, featuring Ives Series Artist-Faculty performing a program of music by Ives and his contemporaries that use folk music in creative ways, a hallmark of Ives' music.

August 8th: Enduring Traditions, featuring Ives Series Guest Artists Julian Schwarz (cello) and Marika Bournaki (piano) performing a program of American music spanning from the 19th century  to today's 21st century composers, including our composer-in-residence, Justin Dello Joio.

August 10th: Harmony, featuring a collaboration between CMI participants and Ives Series Artist-Faculty followed by Ives Series Guest Artist Charles Yang (violin) and Peter Dugan (piano). 

August 12th: The Ives Living Legacy: Today's American Compsoers, featuring Ives Series Artist-Faculty and Ives Series Guest Artist Simon Boyar (percussion) performing the works of Ives and today's American composers, including 2017 featured composer Max Grafe, composer-in-residence Justin Dello Joio, David Ludwig, Kevin Puts, Caroline Shaw, the winner of our call for scores, and Paul Frucht, our artistic director. 

Our Artist-Faculty include: Isabel Hagen (viola), Hannah Ji (violin), Ben Laude (piano), Mitch Lyon (cello), Ariana Nelson (cello), Mika Sasaki (piano), Jacob Shack (viola), Caeli Smith (viola), and Chelsea Starbuck Smith (violin). Read about them here: http://danburymusiccentre.org/c-ives-artists/

2. Your support goes toward the commissioning of living American composers. 

Last year we launched our Composer-in-Residence and Featured Composer programs. This year those programs are continuing and we're introducing a call for scores. The next step in doing our part to support composers is to start commissioning them. We want to commission our first composer in 2019 and no later than 2020.

3. Your support goes toward programming additional concerts and inviting additional artists in the future. 
When we launched CMI in 2015, we invited 6 artist-faculty members and 2 guest artists. Two years later, we've invited 9 artist-faculty members and 5 guest artists. In addition to our 4 annual August concerts, we programmed two additional spring concerts in 2016, and three additional spring concerts in 2017 for a total of 7 concerts this year. The math here is a no-brainer. The more artists on our roster, the more concerts we can program (and with greater flexibility). The more concerts we can program, the more we can program the work of living composers and serve our community. Eventually, we'd like to have 10-15 concerts year round including our week of 4 every August. 

4. Your support goes toward supporting and expanding opportunities for young composers in the future.

Currently we have a composition program through the Chamber Music Intensive that offers program participants the opportunity to write two works each year: one for other instrumental participants to perform and another for artist-faculty to read and record. Participants also work with the Ives Series Composer-in-Residence through lessons and master classes. With your support, we can expand this opportunity to offer more composers this opportunity as well as new ones, such as a young composers concert on the Charles Ives Concert Series with an expanded Call for Scores serving more composer.

We value every single contribution, no matter how small. The Danbury Music Centre is a 501-(c)(3) organization so every contribution is tax-deductible. 

Our perks range from a thank you in our program to a digital download to a private house concert, but everyone, regardless of contribution size, gets one thing: a recorded personal thank you video by one of our Series Artist-Faculty, Guests Artists, Composer-in-Residence, Featured Composer, and/or Artistic Director. 

*Please note: In the midst of our perk creativity, we'd like to clarify that our composer-themed perks do not denote any value judgement about the composers based on the monetary amounts they're associated with!

Aren't able to donate at this time?

That's ok! We understand not everyone who feels passionate about what we're trying to accomplish is necessarily financially able to donate. So here are some other ways you can help:

-Share our campaign with your friends or on social media and tag The Danbury Music Centre.

-Spread the word about our concerts, which you can read about here:

http://danburymusiccentre.org/charles-ives-conc...

-Tell us you're interested in what we're doing and we'll put you on our mailing list.

-If you're local, let us know if you'd like to volunteer. We always are in need of additional help on the ground! 

E-mail us at CMI@danburymusiccentre.org

Thank you for your support!

-Danbury Music Centre

story:
The Story

Formed out of a desire to help our diverse communities be stronger, together, Philly Music Hall is a culmination of years of passionate ideas, debates, and dreams of how the scene 'could be'. Through social events, educational opportunities, and a comprehensive intentional space policy, we will offer the overlapping sex-positive communities of Philadelphia a home base to learn, socialize, and thrive together.

Philly Music Hall will operate as an intentional community center and play space. Founded by community event promoters with over a decade of experience in creating diverse systems outside of traditional event models, Philly Music Hall will alter how Philadelphia’s alternative sexual communities operate by lowering the barrier to entry for new events and giving the community a place to call home.

 

How Will Events at Philly Music Hall Work?

Social events will be a large portion of the weekend schedule. This schedule will include standard monthly parties and gatherings, along with quarterly niche community events. Philly Music Hall will provide the communities it serves the intentional social space they need to develop and grow throughout the week as well. Potlucks, brunch munches, and game nights are just a few of the events on the programming schedule! Recognizing that these groups have varying needs, we plan to primarily partner with and provide resources to community groups and organizers who would like to create amazing events and intentional spaces.

Education

All communities benefit from the opportunity to learn, and Philly Music Hall will utilize a variety of educational formats to engage members and help them learn skills and knowledge that will enrich their lives. Skill shares, discussion groups, and intensives will provide individual niche groups time to both socialize and build/develop skills. The space will be filled with all the equipment needed to provide education on a wide array of topics, as well as couches and social spaces to facilitate small group discussion and hands-on teaching.

We will also offer two classes a month of curated education by Philly Music Hall staff, with regional presenters teaching a diverse set of topics relevant to community interests.

 

Memberships

Members of alternative sexual communities are generally accustomed to spaces and events that charge visitors a per-event rate at the door. While this works for some individuals, it is prohibitively expensive to others; the more invested in the community a person is, the more expensive keeping up becomes. Philly Music Hall will change that by offering a new model to the Philadelphia community; a vetted membership program, similar to a gym membership. While individuals may of course opt to continue paying a per-event fee if that makes sense for their situation, we feel that the community will largely recognize the value of being able to enter events without paying at the door every time.

A standard membership will cost $50 a month, and will include free entry to all parties organized by Philly Music Hall itself (3-6/month), and a vastly reduced charge for parties sponsored by outside groups or individuals (1-3/month). This membership also includes free entry into all discussion groups/skill shares and lab time. Members will have the opportunity to rent space for private events, and rent lockers to store gear over time. They will also receive discounts on larger events sponsored by Philly Music Hall and other partnering organizations.

Philly Music Hall will also offer a platinum membership option, which will include free entry to all events held at the space, a locker, and access to the space throughout the week as a co-working space.



So, why the need for a crowdfund campaign throughout the month of February?

The purpose of this crowdfunding campaign is to raise funds to make Philly Music Hall into the BEST possible environment for communities to gather and grow FROM DAY ONE. Simply put, these funds will be used to make up the difference between “making due with limited resources” and “opening with as many amenities as possible”.

Here is how we plan to spend the money:

Venue Customization

  •  Construction of modular rooms, spaces, and furnishings; to allow a broad variety of special interest organizations to cater the environment to their specific aesthetic
  • Lockers and shelving for members to use
  • Coworking spaces for the office-share
  • Comfortable lounge furniture throughout
  • Modern audio, video, and mood lighting throughout
  • Decor

Technology

  • Philly Music Hall’s digital portal and online community will give members the ability to renew or upgrade their memberships, participate in polls, surveys and forums, socialize with other members, and submit feedback and programming requests
  • Website front-end, back-end, database architecture & management, and servers
     

Programming & Operations

  • Funding the creation of Philly Music Hall’s first niche community parties and events
  • Creating an educational programming schedule that serves as many community members as possible (sponsoring speakers, workshops, intensives)
  • Raise first three months of operating expenses to provide stability to our new business and membership model

 

​Donor Perks

Our Indiegogo allows for you to access Philly Music Hall educational and social events throughout the Spring and Summer, while also becoming an early supporter of this new community space. The perks include:

  • Philly Music Hall memberships, along with funder-exclusive hoodies and shirts!
  • Tickets to upcoming events like Dark Odyssey Fusion, RambleGRUE 3, PittGRUE, and more!
  • Exclusive intensives with a variety of nationally recognized educators like Graydancer, Frozen Meursault, and Lew Rubens!
  • Photoshoots with some of the best photographers in the country like DomWithLens and BDSLR!


We hope everyone takes advantage of our diverse collection of perks! If you have something you’d like to see us offer, feel free to contact us at admin@phillymusichall.com

 

Perk Notes:

Memberships & Vetting - If you purchase a membership, it will begin the first time you visit our space. You'll need to register at our front desk upon entry to get your member card, and will need to sign our member contract and liability waiver. Your membership will entitle you to member prices on events; however, until you have become vetted, you may not attend members-only events. To become vetted, you'll need two vetting references, or a referral from the leadership of one of the participating groups of Philly Music Hall's Advisory Board. There are only a few fully member-exclusive events, and we'll send out plenty of info on how to become vetted before our doors open, so don't stress about it!

Guest Passes:  Many of our perks include guest passes or party passes. There's a difference! For guest passes, they will be sent to you as one-time codes which you (or a friend of your choice) may use to enter any single standard monthly or quarterly event. These passes will NOT get you into annual events such as RambleGRUE, Philly GRUE, or intensive workshops such as Graydancer and Naiia's Power Exchange Intensive or the DomWithLens Photo Afternoon. 

Party passes: For intensive workshops, you'll receive party passes, which will allow you to enter the after-party on the day of the intensive! These passes are automatically included with your intensive ticket, and are not usable on other events.

story:
Short Summary

Jones Beach Bangers have been a tradition for a couple of years now each year surpassing the last. Along with the wholesome fun (football, kan jam, socializing, etc.) it is going to be a legendary day of rowdiness that you have all been hearing about.

What to expect:

  • Sports/tailgating games
  • Girls in bikinis looking fine
  • Most people in rare form
  • New friendships
  • Some stories to not tell the kids when you are older

What We Need

As you can imagine some planning and foresight goes in to this event. We need your help to get the necessary supplies. We need at least $600 to get this party going. The more we raise the more things we can get.

The money is going to:

  • Two new loud ass speakers
  • Trash bags (Let's try to keep it clean)
  • Party games
  • A lot of cups

The Impact

Live life for the experiences and continue to make this day a tradition for years to come:

  • Partying with our friends and letting loose is part of our culture. Keep it loose baby.
  • Summer 2017 only comes round once.

Ground Rules

Although this gathering is a lot of fun people are reminded that they are liable for their conduct and possibly the conduct of their friends if it comes down to it.

  • You are responsible for the things you bring on to the beach.
  • Fighting is frowned upon and everyone will chant "asshole" as you get shunned and thrown out.

Other Ways You Can Help

This day is what you make it and you can help by lending a hand:

  • Bring your Kan Jam or cornhole if you have it. The more the merrier. It's sort of like a tailgate on the beach.
  • Come early and dig a sand table that can be utilized in a variety of ways. I will dig one but I probably won't dig two.

If you can contribute a couple of dollars it would be much appreciated. Thank you for the help and support. 

July 15th here we come!

story:
Hello, world! 

We are RAW, Raging Asian Women Taiko Drummers.  Based out of Toronto, we are a community arts collective of East and Southeast Asian Women. We are a Taiko (Japanese) drumming group that exists as a critical response and challenge to both systemic and internalized oppressions. Through performance, education, and community outreach, we seek to challenge, redefine and represent ourselves, and to inspire others.  In short hand, we are at the intersection of art and activism.

In 2012, RAW mounted the very first Toronto Taiko Festival.  On the west coast, Taiko drumming was instrumental in creating and celebrating Asian, Asian-American, and Asian-Canadian history, culture, identity, and communities.  We had felt the need and desire to create the same in our region.  To that end, 2012 TTF was a great success.

We are back to organize the 2nd festival in August, an exciting 3-day festival filled with workshops, a concert, and a public forum.  Featured guest artists including  Joe Small from LA; Mark H Rooney from Washington DC; Kristy Oshiro of Sacramento, CA; and the honorable PJ Hirabayashi from San Jose, CA.  We also have guest groups from Montreal and Ottawa.

We are a grassroots organization and this is a grass-roots festival.  Read between the lines…we have very little money! Every donation, whether small or large, will mean a great deal to us.  Your contribution is going towards…well, what isn’t it going towards!  Honorariums for the workshop teachers, venue rental, stage crew fees, drum rentals, posters, performer honorariums, van rental (to move the drums), food to feed the teachers, and other publicity needs (website).  AND for the first time, we have paid festival staff (who would like to get paid for their work!).  We are cutting costs where we can (asking for people to open up their homes for hosting, asking for service donations, lots of volunteers!), but we still need to pay the bills. 

Toronto Taiko Festival is growing and we foresee that we will continue to mount this culturally important event for a long time to come.  We celebrate this art form that speaks to us of our past heritage...and open it to share with the world!

Help us spread the word!!!  Go to www.torontotaikofestival.org for more info. 

 

Thank you!!

Raging Asian Women

story:
Read more about Inheritance Year Here

Recently Wrapped Programs:

  • LooseLeaf Volume 7+8 Launch - Volume 7 (funded by OAC), Volume 8 (staff anthology)
     
  • Diasporasian Futures (funded through Artreach x TAC)
    • Diasporasian Futures is a month-long incubator program for artists and community art organizers to develop tangible skills and realize their creative visions.
  • Wear We Came From (self-funded)
    • Wear We Came From is a photo-audio series documenting ten young Asian individuals living in the GTA and their stories of migration, told through clothing and accessories.

Upcoming Programs:

  • Traces II (self-funded)
    • Traces II is our second season of video interviews, mapping the artistic process and practice of creatives in various fields through video interviews.
  • LooseLeaf Blog (self-funded)
    • LooseLeaf Blog includes reviews on books, events, and theatre. It is the place to critically engage with the creative output in Toronto without just talking about representation.
  • LooseLeaf Volume 9 (self-funded)
    • LooseLeaf Volume 9 is our last print volume. Themed around "Power", Volume 9 will feature prose, poetry, non-fiction, comics, photography, visual art and media art in print and digital formats.
  • LooseLeaf 3D - Precarious Joy (self-funded / TAC Grant Pending)
    • LooseLeaf 3D is our last volume in an exhibition format. This two-week interdisciplinary art exhibition honours our community by grounding ourselves in the present and activating joy as communal resistance.
       

Project 40 began as a collaborative online platform idea in early 2015. Our collective emerged from the communal need for supportive spaces that understood the diasporic, historical contexts that Asian creators work in and from, and a desire to intentionally engage with what it meant to be an emerging Asian.Canadian creative. We operate from a grassroots, decolonial lens, situating our programming in communal relations, reflexivity and accountability.

Almost five years later, we're a full-fledged artist collective. 

We've incubated 8 interdisciplinary Col.lab projects, published 8 LooseLeaf Magazines, hosted 7 launches, 5 art exhibitions, launched two blogs featuring interviews and reviews, run a variety of subsidized workshops, socials, a mini-conference, and an incubator.

We've met over 100 artists in all kinds of imaginable disciplines, built relationships, partnered on projects, had food and drink, and complained through all iterations of Toronto's weather.

It has been a magical 5 years full of communal life in all its ups and downs, joys and pains. 

Meet the P40 x LooseLeaf staff who have been faithfully supporting our programming over the years!

Project 40 Collective Staff: Jasmine Gui, Abby Ho, Mirae Lee, Jing Tey
Tech Support: Elliott Jun, Errol Cheong
A/V Support: Peter Ko

Past Staff: Winnie Wong

LooseLeaf Masthead
Managing Editors: Jasmine Gui, Abby Ho
Poetry: Natalie Wee, Elise Yoon, Isabelle Zhu
Fiction: Elliott Jun, Victoria Liao, Elizabeth Ching
Visual Art: Amanda Low, Philip Leonard Ocampo, Rose Ho
Photography: Lucy Lu
Layout: Anna Kwan

LooseLeaf Digital: Aliya Ghare, Linh Nguyen
Past Masthead: Anne Tom Wong, Rebecca Yu, Chloe Leung








Share, Like, Send us a love letter, hold us accountable, attend our events, tell people about us! 

We're so grateful to everyone for blessing us with your wonderful creative energy, company and labour over the last few years. Thank you for existing in our community. We love you!

story:
Podcasts are changing the world. They’re building communities, extending empathy, bringing laughter, and making the dishes just way more pleasant to wash. We (the people who started PodCon) are fascinated by all of this, and we love this art form.

In 2017, we gathered fans, creators, and industry in one place to celebrate podcasts. Whether it’s news, interview, scripted, comedy, advice, true crime, gaming, fiction, or nonfiction storytelling, it’s new, it’s exciting, and we love it. The first PodCon was amazing. Now, January 19th and 20th, we are doing it again.

PodCon features live podcasts, panel discussions, workshops, connections, networking opportunities, mashups, and meet and greets. It's an event designed for creators, fans, and industry, and every session is open to all attendees. 

PodCon is brought to you by co-founders Hank Green, Joseph Fink, Jeffrey Cranor, Travis McElroy, and Justin McElroy.

Podcasting is a broad medium, which is a fancy way of saying that there are a LOT of people podcasting. Some have humongous audiences, others do not. And many people with smaller audiences nonetheless have more passionate and engaged listeners. If you have suggestions for people you think we should invite or ideas for content in general, we would love to hear from you! Please fill out this form.

The more backers we get, the more podcasters we can bring out to PodCon. We'll be announcing new guests regularly throughout the campaign (and afterward) to our backers.

For less reliable updates, follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Cascade, and Berfd.

Live Podcasts

You know, like when a podcast happens but there are a bunch of people in the room? These will also include our patented (not really) Podcast Scrambles where we take two unrelated hosts and force them to create a one-off podcast together. It's magic, and it is one of our favorite things we did last year.

Panel Discussions

We've got challenges, so we've got DISCUSSIONS! These might be cultural, technological, financial, or social, or maybe even a combination of those things. We need to talk this stuff out in the moments when we can, and hopefully do it in a way that is entertaining for both creators and fans.

Workshops

We all want to learn from the best. Whether that's writing fiction, capturing truth in audio, community building, or technical skills (no one wants to sound like they recorded on a toaster), we'll have experts at PodCon talking you through it.

Weirdness

We tend to find that, when you get a lot of talented, creative people in the same building, things just happen. We start asking our guests for ideas and suddenly there are improv gaming sessions, puppet shows, role playing games, and who knows what else.

Remember:

Even if you are unable to attend PodCon, you can get all of this stuff in your podcast feed with a secret RSS feed if you pledge at our "Remote Attendance" level. 

Do I have to have a podcast to attend?
Oh no! The majority of stuff at PodCon is for fans of podcasts (which, of course, includes everyone who makes podcasts.) All of our main-stage content is, in our opinion, enjoyable even if you've never listened to a podcast. And even the panels or workshops that we have at PodCon aimed at people who are creating podcasts, we hope, will be interesting for diehard fans who want a peak behind the curtain. 

What if the IndieGoGo doesn’t reach its goal?
There are some things we want to do that we won't be able to do, but the show will go on! As more money comes in, we're able to invite more podcasters and expand the scope of the event. Everything we've promised here so far is definitely happening.

Will I be able to get this stuff after the IndieGoGo ends?
Tickets will still be available (though they will go up in price) as well as swag bags and the remote attendance podcast feed. Everything else is campaign-only!  

Will there be live shows at PodCon?
Yep!

What about Night Vale and The Adventure Zone?
Because of the complexity of those shows, they will be hosting off-site shows that will be separately ticketed.

Can I upgrade my perk in the future if I have more money?
The way to do this would be to cancel the original perk and buy the new perk while the campaign is still going on. Unfortunately, there is no easy way to upgrade perks.

I have a podcast, can I get involved?
Obviously, there are a huge number of amazing and popular podcasts out there. We’re looking to represent a broad range of podcasts in both size and genre, but of course, we can’t feature everyone. You can fill out this form to let us know you’re interested.

Can I suggest a podcast?
Yes! Of course. Please fill out this form.

I’m thinking about coming alone, is that OK?
Definitely. We will have an optional gathering for lone attendees if you want to attempt to break the ice with some other people. 

I can't get to Seattle!!
We’ve got a “Remote Attendance” perk just for you! We will not be able to stream any of PodCon live, but “Remote Attendance” backers will get access to a password protected podcast link. All recorded content from PodCon including live podcasts, mashups, and panels will be delivered into your favorite podcast listening software. 

I (or a company I represent) would like to help more than $900 worth of help and am interested in sponsorship.
EMAIL US THAT SOUNDS REALLY GREAT info@podcon.com

How does priority seating work?
Before a panel or event begins, a priority seating area will be set aside. These seats are not assigned, and there is a chance that they will all fill. They will have a better than average view of the stage / content, and they will be fairly numerous. Ten minutes before the content is scheduled to begin, these sections will be opened to all attendees, so your seat is only saved if you show up before the content, not forever. 

Will there be a chance for meet-ups and autographs?
Yes! Not everyone will be doing this, but we will be using a lottery system to assign meet and greets for people who are interested in them.

This actually sounds really great, why haven't I backed this thing yet?
We have no idea.

Is there any other way I can help?
YES. Please please please tell everyone you know who loves podcasts that they need to check this thing out. 

I have a question that wasn't answered here.
Please check out podcon.com for more information, or email info@podcon.com your question and we will get back to you.
story_txt: Podcasts are changing the world. They’re building communities, extending empathy, bringing laughter, and making the dishes just way more pleasant to wash. We (the people who started PodCon) are fascinated by all of this, and we love this art form.In 2017, we gathered fans, creators, and industry in one place to celebrate podcasts. Whether it’s news, interview, scripted, comedy, advice, true crime, gaming, fiction, or nonfiction storytelling, it’s new, it’s exciting, and we love it. The first PodCon was amazing. Now, January 19th and 20th, we are doing it again.PodCon features live podcasts, panel discussions, workshops, connections, networking opportunities, mashups, and meet and greets. It's an event designed for creators, fans, and industry, and every session is open to all attendees. PodCon is brought to you by co-founders Hank Green, Joseph Fink, Jeffrey Cranor, Travis McElroy, and Justin McElroy.Podcasting is a broad medium, which is a fancy way of saying that there are a LOT of people podcasting. Some have humongous audiences, others do not. And many people with smaller audiences nonetheless have more passionate and engaged listeners. If you have suggestions for people you think we should invite or ideas for content in general, we would love to hear from you! Please fill out this form.The more backers we get, the more podcasters we can bring out to PodCon. We'll be announcing new guests regularly throughout the campaign (and afterward) to our backers.For less reliable updates, follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Cascade, and Berfd.Live PodcastsYou know, like when a podcast happens but there are a bunch of people in the room? These will also include our patented (not really) Podcast Scrambles where we take two unrelated hosts and force them to create a one-off podcast together. It's magic, and it is one of our favorite things we did last year.Panel DiscussionsWe've got challenges, so we've got DISCUSSIONS! These might be cultural, technological, financial, or social, or maybe even a combination of those things. We need to talk this stuff out in the moments when we can, and hopefully do it in a way that is entertaining for both creators and fans.WorkshopsWe all want to learn from the best. Whether that's writing fiction, capturing truth in audio, community building, or technical skills (no one wants to sound like they recorded on a toaster), we'll have experts at PodCon talking you through it.WeirdnessWe tend to find that, when you get a lot of talented, creative people in the same building, things just happen. We start asking our guests for ideas and suddenly there are improv gaming sessions, puppet shows, role playing games, and who knows what else.Remember:Even if you are unable to attend PodCon, you can get all of this stuff in your podcast feed with a secret RSS feed if you pledge at our "Remote Attendance" level. Do I have to have a podcast to attend?Oh no! The majority of stuff at PodCon is for fans of podcasts (which, of course, includes everyone who makes podcasts.) All of our main-stage content is, in our opinion, enjoyable even if you've never listened to a podcast. And even the panels or workshops that we have at PodCon aimed at people who are creating podcasts, we hope, will be interesting for diehard fans who want a peak behind the curtain. What if the IndieGoGo doesn’t reach its goal?There are some things we want to do that we won't be able to do, but the show will go on! As more money comes in, we're able to invite more podcasters and expand the scope of the event. Everything we've promised here so far is definitely happening.Will I be able to get this stuff after the IndieGoGo ends?Tickets will still be available (though they will go up in price) as well as swag bags and the remote attendance podcast feed. Everything else is campaign-only!  Will there be live shows at PodCon?Yep!What about Night Vale and The Adventure Zone?Because of the complexity of those shows, they will be hosting off-site shows that will be separately ticketed.Can I upgrade my perk in the future if I have more money?The way to do this would be to cancel the original perk and buy the new perk while the campaign is still going on. Unfortunately, there is no easy way to upgrade perks.I have a podcast, can I get involved?Obviously, there are a huge number of amazing and popular podcasts out there. We’re looking to represent a broad range of podcasts in both size and genre, but of course, we can’t feature everyone. These seats are not assigned, and there is a chance that they will all fill. They will have a better than average view of the stage / content, and they will be fairly numerous. Ten minutes before the content is scheduled to begin, these sections will be opened to all attendees, so your seat is only saved if you show up before the content, not forever. Will there be a chance for meet-ups and autographs?Yes! story:
Inspire crossart creativity-solidarity without borders and intergenerational interaction

"Mahabharabbit", our community musical theatre is a completely handmade and essentially interactive cross-art project. It is an original play that is going to be performed by more than 60 participants in Mytilene and Mantamados, two towns of Lesvos, on 4th and 6th of May, 2018. Two intercultural choirs, "Cantalaloun" and "Polyphonica Aegean" take part. These choirs have been set up in 2016 on Lesvos island and are kindly supported by Mosaik Support Centre for refugees and Lesvos Primary Education Directorate. Community artists, such as  Body Percussion group KEKEÇA, Fred Normal, Yioula Koutsoumpou and Stefanos Filos are closely collaborating and have contributed to this particular project's implementation. Inspired by the Cataclysm myth found in many cultures and parts of the world, such as in the Hindu epic "Mahabharrata", our contemporary narration shows a global garbage flood as a result of excessive consumption and self centerness of the 21st century. Our play is crossing borders of all kinds: languages, cultures, generations, artistic fields, between performers and audience, between professionals and amateurs. In the new land where we land after flying over the current Catastrophe, our pigeons-children spread the message of solidarity, respect, love and creativity as the main solution that can actually save us.

This is our second big show, after last years' musical circus theatre "Opera Babel' and is included in the series of "Balance & Harmony" artistic works.

Your contribution is critical as it will help us with a lot of practicalities that cannot be made out of trash (such as our costumes and scenery), but should be bought. Also, by supporting us, you make it possible for our guest artists to join us here, in Lesvos (travel and food costs). Empowering people to experience art in a mostly hands-on, interactive way and at the same time raising awareness about current Human Crisis is at the center of our motivation.

story:
//FOR ENGLISH SCROLL DOWN

Mi a küldetésünk?

A fesztivál célja olyan közeget teremteni ahol a sokszínű alkotói közösség fórumot találhat, ahol a jelenlevő művészek párbeszédet kezdeményezhetnek egymással. A fesztivál otthonául továbbra is a nagy utaktól távol fekvő kistelepülést akartunk választani. Végül a nógrád megyei Garáb község ajánlotta fel, hogy idén befogadja az eseményt. Tapasztalataink szerint a városi közegtől való távolság és a természetközeliség elmélyíti és kiteljesíti az együtt töltött időt. A Fesztivál a nevét alapítónk, Hajnóczy Csaba Kampec Dolores nevű zenekarának albumáról kapta, amit egy bibliai hasonlat ihletett. Mi is évről évre be akarjuk bizonyítani, hogy lehetséges a mai Magyarországon egy non-profit közösségi eseményt létrehozni, hogy újra és újra átférünk a tű fokán!

Ehhez szükségünk van a ti támogatásotokra is!

A program

Idén is folytatjuk a hagyományokat és komolyabb és könnyedebb zenéket igyekszünk összefűzni mozgással, színházzal és irodalmi eseményekkel. 

Egyelőre több külföldi vendéggel tárgyalunk:

  • Szeretnénk meghívni a '70-es években legendássá vált, első és meghatározó krautrock zenekart, a német faUStot.
  • A cseh avant/punk Uz jsme doma szerepel még a tervezett műsorban. 
  • Ezen túl több dél-olasz világzenei zenekarral egyeztetünk, a célunk, hogy egy igazi tarantella műsort hozzunk el végre Magyarországra. 
  • A nagyszínpadon szerepeltetnénk még valmelyik ismeretebb magyar alternatív előadót illetve a jazz/zaj zenei vonalból a Landing Venust vagy egy másik a szcénából érkező zenekart.

A kisszínpad műsorát néhány visszatérő vendégen túl (Halálorgazmus, Presszó Tangó Libidó) idén is a szentendrei Elevenkert, a veszprémi Utcazene, vagy a kapolcsi Művészetek Völgye eseményein ismertté vált előadókkal tarkítjuk.

A Garábi templomban délutánonként klasszikus zenei programot tervezünk.

Éjjelente a színpadi programok után idén is várunk mindenkit egyik legkülönlegesebb élményünkre a szabad természetben megrendezett teljesen akusztikus sokszor meditatív jellegű előadásainkra.

Eddig tervezett műhelyeink:

  • Sőrés Zsolt, zenei szabadimprovizáció
  • Szamosi Judit, Testidő
  • FauSt
  • Kontakttánc, szabadmozgás.
  • Örömzenélés Csatlós Marciékkal

Terveink között szerepel még egy fórumszínházas előadás, jóga, számháború, és éjjelente közös tábortüzes zenélés.

Hogy működik ez?

Minden programunk megszervezése bizonyos mennyiségű pénzt igényel. Minnél több pénzt sikerül összegyűjtenünk, annál több programot tudunk megszervezni. A támogatásért cserébe a fesztivál látogatását lehetővé tévő karszalagot, ételt, ajándéktárgyakat ajánlunk nektek. Miután összegyűlik a szükséges összeg, tájékoztatást adunk, hogy az mire elég a program szempontjából és mennyire lenne szükségünk, hogy még több eseményt szervezhessünk. Idén a minimális összeg, amire szükségünk van 3000 dollár, amiből a különböző levonások után nagyjából 750.000 forint érkezik meg hozzánk.

A szállásról

Különböző okok miatt, de ott kellett hagynunk eddigi településünket Cserhátszentivánt és új otthont kerestünk. Garábon egy csodálatos vendégházat találtunk, aminek a kertjében lehetőség lesz sátrakat verni. Azonban a vendégeink számára korlátozott számban lehetőség van 5-6 ágyas szobákban is kibérelni egy ágyat. Garáb egy körülbelül 40 fős település úgyhogy méreteiből adódóan ez az egy lehetőség van helyben szobákban aludni. Így aztán akit nem vonz a nomádabb sátrazás annak javasoljuk, hogy lehetőség szerint hamar foglalja le ezen a lapon a szállását magának, mielőtt elfogynak az ágyak.

(A forintban kiírt összegek tájékoztató jellegűek, az aktuális forint-dollár árfolyam függvényében ingadozhatnak)

// ENGLISH

Our Mission

The mission of this festival is to find an environment where diverse groups of creators find a forum to share and have a conversation with each other. For the home of the festival we have chosen a small village far off the beaten path. This year the village of Garáb in Nógrád county Hungary, a village of only 42 inhabitants has come forth to host our event. According to our experience the distance from urbanised places, and being close to nature consummates the time spent together. The festival, that’s got it’s name from a biblical parable (Tű Fokán literally translates to “The eye of the needle”) is also the title of one of the albums of our founder Csaba Hajnóczy. Our mission is to prove that even in the given political circumstances we can still make a non-profit festival in Hungary, that we can again fit through the eye of the needle. To be able to do that we are asking for your support.

The program

This year we are continuing with our traditions we want to make a program that combines different fields of music with theatre, improvisation, movement, and literature. We are in the process of finding agreement with different performers. The main ones we would love to see at this years’ festival are:

  • The german band faUSt, that became legendery in the 70’s as the first and foremost krautrock group.
  • The czech avant/punk Us jsme doma.
  • We’s like to find a southern italian world music group and bring a full performance of tarantella power to Hungary.
  • On our main stage we would have several an alternative Hungarian groups as well, including Kampec Dolores, Landing Venus, and one of the old style alternative rock bands as well.

On out half-accoustic afternoon stage we will have once again several hungarian musicians whom are known from hungarian festivals like the Valley of Arts or the Street Music Festival in Veszprém.

In the small church of the village we plan to make short sessions of classical music every day.

During the night after the main stage closes we invite our audience for our most special experience full accoustic, often meditative concerts outside the village in the forest, with only torches and a sky full of stars. 

Our planned workshops at the moment are

  • Zsolt Sőrés, free improvisation
  • Judit Szamosi, Body Time
  • One workshop of contactt improvisation we are still negotiating.
  • Jamming and Storytelling with Marci Csatlós

We are also planning to have a performance of forum theatre, have yoga everyday, and late nights have a campfire with musical jams and singing.

How does this work?

All of our programs require a certain amount of money. The more money we get, the programs we can organise. For your support we offer you festival passes, food, Tű Fokán posters or T-Shirts or accomodation. If we get to our target money we will tell you where it gets us program wise and what we can do if more money comes in.

Accomodation

For different reasons we had to move to a nearby village from our usual spot, where we have more limited accomodation. Besides putting up a tent (for that we have plenty of space) we only have our small guest house where we can offer you beds in rooms of 5-7 beds. You can choose the appropriate perk to reserve your accomodation for a given day of the festival. 

Perks

Traslation for the items you get that at this point unfortunately can’t be translated to english on the perks list anymore:

3 napos jegy = 3 days pass that you can use on any consecutive 3 days of the festival

Thank you for all the support you can give! Let's make it happen!

If we get to our target money we will tell you where it gets us program wise and what we can do if more money comes in.AccomodationFor different reasons we had to move to a nearby village from our usual spot, where we have more limited accomodation. Besides putting up a tent (for that we have plenty of space) we only have our small guest house where we can offer you beds in rooms of 5-7 beds. You can choose the appropriate perk to reserve your accomodation for a given day of the festival. PerksTraslation for the items you get that at this point unfortunately can’t be translated to english on the perks list anymore:3 napos jegy = 3 days pass that you can use on any consecutive 3 days of the festivalThank you for all the support you can give! Let's make it happen!

story:
Our mission statement is to support parents in helping their children become multi-lingual by teaching their children to speak the language fluently in a friendly environment.

Term dates and age groups

The term will start in September 2019. The class dates for autumn term are 14. September, 28. September, 12. October, 2. November, 16. November, 30. November and 14. December. Classes will be held at Montem Primary School, Islington, from 10am to 12 pm. Toddler group is available for children in nursery and reception class, born from 1. September 2014 to 31. August 2016. Primary class is available for children in year 1 to 6, born from 1. September 2008 to 31. August 2014. 

This first term is our pilot, and if we are successful we aim to expand the school to operate on every Saturday in all three school terms.

Fees for autumn 2019

  • £15 per session per child (first child)

  • £12 per session per sibling

The fees are payable upfront per term and are not refundable. We collect the fees using the crowd funding platform Indigogo. Please select a "perk" according to how many children will attend.

How much we need to raise

In order for the Icelandic school to become a reality, we need to raise a total of £1,000 through fees and sponsorships. This covers classroom rent, teachers' pay and other costs. If not enough children sign up to make the school viable, you will be refunded.

Who are we

The Icelandic School in London is run as a non-profit by volunteers. We are parents of children who have Icelandic as a second language and we all have full time jobs in different industries. If you want to volunteer and lend us a hand, don't hesitate to get in touch.

Check out our Facebook page for more.

Where are the classes

The Icelandic School in London will be held in Montem Primary school, where we will have access to excellent classrooms and facilities. Montem is in Islington, close to Finsbury Park which has commuting links across London.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, this is Aaron & Levi, co-founders of Circadian Rhythms and this is our story. We are brothers, multi-instrumentalists, live performers, environmentalists and van lifers who love drumming. Drums are a huge part of our lives and the music we create. Our band VanderAa is an expression of organic sounds using drums, beatboxing, didgeridoo, guitar, and vocals enhanced by technology that create compositions transcending realms of indie roots, alternative pop rock and world music. 

This campaign is everything to us. Since creating Circadian Rhythms we see how important this drum circle is to us and the Sunshine Coast community. We highly value this space for our community to come together, connect and express ourselves through the power of music and dance.

Each individual pledge/donation is helping to SAVE CIRCADIAN RHYTHMS and get this community back to life. This will be laying the foundation of circadian rhythms for years to come! If 8 months of Circadian Rhythms has seen friendships form, mental health improve, events grow and collectives create, imagine the Sunshine Coast in ten years time. A vibrant, diverse, expressive, connected community.

If Covid has taught us anything, it is that we need this space for our community to come together. Globally we are in a state of disconnect, separation and fear. Let's continue to build our communities back into safe spaces to combat the health and well being of our people. 

What We Need & What You Get

Circadian Rhythms needs $2892 to create a not for profit. This enables us to keep it FREE for the community and keep the medicine accessible for all. By creating a not for profit it waives council fees of getting Circadian Rhythms back in Tickle Park, Coolum Beach. 

This gets Circadian Rhythms back on the main strip of Coolum Beach. This will be establishing circadian rhythms as a community space we can rely on to uplift, cultivate personal and professional connections, generate health and well-being, promote events and express ourselves creatively.  

The Funds will be going specifically into the following things for the future sustainability of Circadian Rhythms:

Set up costs for not for profit - $2892

Public Liability Insurance - $800 (annual) 

Admin which includes signage, hand sanitiser, first aid kit - $300 (annual) 

 

Total: $3,992 

Any extra money that we fundraiser will go towards future infrastructure (i.e rubbish collection, instruments). 

Your contribution will make a huge difference for our community. This is vital for us, for our community to continue to prosper, for the arts, for our wellbeing and for us to unite. You can help us make a difference, by building Coolum Beach as a cultural hub where we can make a difference for our local economy, local business’, tourism and our precious environment. The fundamental values of this community are built on being the change we want to see in the world.

Circadian Rhythms is off to a great start with a great track record. It has birthed and assisted in the creation of community activities such as Secret Garden Experience (VanderAa music festival), Liquid Lyrics (poetry slam), Conscious Fire Circus, Noosa Environmental Education, Circadian Rhythms Beach Clean up (environmental), Circadian Rhythms School (education), Wolf Medicine (men's mental health group) and many other local events and organisations. 

These connections and events are having real impacts on our lives. We’ve planted 100 trees, cleaned beaches, increased the health and well-being of the community and much more. 

Risks & Challenges

Rubbish! As this community grows in size so does our rubbish footprint. Even though the culture of this event is ‘No trace’. We still have rubbish leftover from newcomers and people drinking alcohol. As we continue to educate our leave no trace culture our community has created a solution. Every monday night  after the drum circle there will be a Circadian Rhythms Beach Clean up.  We will also planting trees to carbon offset our eco footprint if you wish to be envolved with our Environemental Team sign up here; https://www.vanderaaband.com/environmental-team

If you can't contribute financially that is okay! We are all abundant in different ways. What is your creative genius? What is your gift? Do you have a strong social media presence? Sharing this campaign can help. Share this story with your people. Do you have spare time to volunteer? As Circadian Rhythms grow we will need community support to keep our community nurtured and loved. Please share, reach out and connect.

Much Love Aaron & Levi

story:
- campaign ended - 

The journey was completed successfully, thanks to the wonderful people who backed me. It didn't become what I had initially imagined, but it was one heck of an adventure - soon (TM) to be immortalised in book form.

story:
About us

Eutopya Magazine is an international, entirely student-run magazine committed to the propagation of democratic ideals through truth-telling and freedom of expression. Founded two years ago, we now span three continents, working with correspondents from over 30 countries. We hope to continue growing in size and representation. Our magazine aims to inspire intellectual debate in young and old alike and to unite the nations - and opinions - of the world through social media.

We know the importance of youth involvement in national and international politics, economics, and global conflicts; as students ourselves, we hold that we have a right to have our voices heard. Every one of us here at Eutopya really believes in the multilateral dream that underpins this project, and we know that, with a structurally unprecedented magazine, we have an opportunity to change the way students across the globe interact with one another.

Visit us at www.eutopya.org

 

Introduction

Help us create a podcast in Thika, Kenya!
Freedom of expression cannot be a privilege only for a few. 
The Eutopya staff has received an incredible invitation from Mohamed  to join him in Thika, and help establish a radio station with local students. This proposal launched plans for Radio Eutopya, a podcast to be run by youth from around the world that will make our movement more accessible to all. Our staff is currently planning its first trip down to Thika this summer, where we will stay with the name of group, who’ve generously agreed to host us. There, we will meet our new partners-in-action - students from Mohamed’s photography school, an institution for local youth interested in the digital arts. 

Help us write our own history, together!

 

 

Partnerships

  • Action for children in conflict (AfCiC) is Kenyan NGO which aims to foster support for local youth and their families, running centers where children can find food, culture and love. Radio Eutopya will be established in partnership with AFICIC and their inspiring staff. 
  • Foundation Piano Terra will support Radio Eutopya, offering its logistic support for our staff volunteers.
     

 

Giving a voice…  

This project is ultimately a manifestation of media in its most pure and human form and will lay the foundations of this global bridge between Thika and the world. Global pluralism through youth empowerment is absolutely possible - it begins with a dream like this one.

While we hope that our podcast will eventually establish numerous worldwide bases, it’s no accident that we are choosing Thika as our first and primary location. Historically, the West has spun its own narrative for Africa, a narrative of suffering and depravity that the West is called upon to “fix."The legacy of this narrative continues on today. Humanitarian organizations often operate under this understanding - that the people of African nations must catch up to the West (be it culturally or “developmentally”) or learn to adapt to the misfortunes that have befallen them. 

Though we stand by the premise of liberal international order, Eutopya was never intended to be a western-dominated organization. It was born from a belief in global pluralism, not western pluralism. In working with Thika youth, we will not be a European humanitarian coalition going in to “help underprivileged locals.” Instead, we are students recognizing an issue and partnering with our peers. As stated above, Eutopya believes in creating a forum where youth can be heard, converse, and unify. With this podcast, we strive to extend the discourse to our Thika peers, giving them a voice and returning to them control over their own narrative. This is our movement - unification across ages, across nations, across races, across cultures, for a better and more just world. The podcast certainly won’t solve the global crisis that is racism, nor will it reverse in any way the colonial legacy in Africa, but we strive to combat injustice nonetheless.

 

Taking the first steps…

Our primary goal is to launch our podcast with these young students from the Thika school. Radio Eutopya from Thika (RET) will be available on Spotify, Spreaker, iTunes and YouTube platforms, and the students will partner with us in podcast scripting and production. 
The radio contents will also be published on our website , part of an active collaboration between the staff on scene and the worldwide editorial staff.
Episodes will include live debates, thematic comparisons, interviews with leading personalities at international level.
Our facilities will be equipped with microphones, mixers, computers, headphones and sound cards - this is where you come in!  

Your generous donations will help our staff to travel to Thika and purchase the necessary equipment. Our magazine is a nonprofit organization, and every euro, pound, and dollar helps!

 

Looking to the future…  

We aim to eventually export our project to other African centers, including Mali, where Mohamed has already started a communal photography studio.

We hope to continue growing our movement and becoming a fully international conglomerate, with stations set up world-wide. This project is ultimately a manifestation of media in its most pure and human form and will lay the foundations of this global bridge between Thika and the world. Global pluralism through youth empowerment is absolutely possible - it begins with a dream like this one.

 

 

Allocation of funds

If we reach €1,000

  • microphone (AKG C3000) x2: about 330 euros with shipping
  • mixer (Xenyx 1204 USB): about 150 euros with shipping
  • headphone (K92 x2): about 150 euros with shipping
  • sound card (Behringer UMC204HD): about 100 euros with shipping
  • various cables and microphone auction: about 50 euros with shipping
  • Spotify, Spreaker, and other platform fees: about 300 euros per year

If we reach €2,000

  • coverage 30% of flight costs: about 1,000 euros
  • in addition to aforementioned equipment

If we reach €3,000

  • i7 8700 desktop PC + keyboard + screen + mouse + speakers: about 850 euros
  • in addition to aforementioned equipment and flight costs

If we reach €4,000

  • coverage of 60% of flight costs: approximately 2,000 euros
  • in addition to aforementioned equipment

If we reach €5,000

  • coverage of 100% of flight costs: approximately 3,000 euros
  • in addition to aforementioned equipment

story:
manchester MODERN

Manchester Modern is a labour of love. Richard Brook began the project in 1996 with a Samsung compact camera, bought from the Argos catalogue – it had the most features and the most extensive zoom range for the cheapest price. He is honest when he states ‘I had no idea what I was doing’; fortunately, he continued. He knew that his fascination with things others found ugly would be worthwhile one day.

This publication has been promised and considered for a long time and has regularly stalled due to lack of funds and an unwillingness on his part, and that of Vaseem Bhatti (the designer), to compromise over the design and manufacture of this guidebook. It is conceived as a field guide, small enough to fit in your pocket, but weighty enough to know its merit. Times have caught up with Richard and what he once considered obscure and rare groove is now (as you know) populist and media friendly. Regardless, the honesty and integrity of this project as a printed and published object is retained and this single opportunity to buy into 20 years of work by one of the leading thinkers and researchers of mainstream modern architecture is presented here.

Steadily, Richard has built a reputation in academic circles and amongst aficionados as a passionate and informed expert in the architecture of the region and of the provinces. That isn’t to say he doesn’t like London, but there’s an established and ready focus upon the architectural narratives of the capital and a distinct sense that the provinces have long been understudied and underexposed. In Manchester Modern we present 111 buildings of the twentieth and early twenty first century, lovingly photographed and researched over, as stated, the last twenty years.

Vaseem is an artist of pedigree and defined the distinctive visual identity of Warp Records’ hip-hop off shoot, Lex Records, as well as being instrumental in the definition of Manchester’s Skam Records and their aesthetic presence in virtual and printed media. He founded EHQuestionmark and has worked with Richard in one form or another for the best part of fifteen years. This coming together of academic and artist has been made possible by the Modernist Society and we are proud to be able to aid Richard and Vaseem in finally delivering this publication, that is long overdue.

The buildings contained in this catalogue have each been visited at least three times by Richard to attain the correct light conditions for his photography. The retrieval of contemporary journal articles in relation to each has meant numerous trips to the RIBA Library in London to access material no longer held in Manchester. The working hours attached to the delivery of the content, let alone the post-editing and design, run into the thousands and in honesty Richard is unable to quantify just what proportion of his life this has consumed. This is a one off print run and will not be reproduced as a second edition, this is your chance to support the continued works of the Modernist Society and to buy into the passion and dedication of one of our most esteemed collaborators.

What We Need & What You Get

We have had a little help from the National Lottery Heritage Fund and a huge input from Richard and Bhatti but in order to get this unique book printed we need to raise a further £7500.

This money will pay for a one off and limited edition print run.

You can help us achieve this by taking up one of our special 'perks'

  • Cardboard
  • PVC
  • Concrete
  • Flesh

The book is conceived as a field guide and as a collectors object and is available in three formats:

Cardboard: The ‘basic’ object is A6 landscape (26x153x111mm), with 240 pages of vanilla white 150gsm uncoated stock lithographed in black and white, and finished with a silver ink highlight. Each case study building is presented across a single spread with two photographs and a descriptive text. The hardback cover is an uncoated grey recycled 2000micron board which is debossed both front and back, with a spine bound by a white foil-blocked, black canvas tape. The casebound sewn pages can be temporarily bookmarked with an orange ribbon, a colour that references the corporate identity of Greater Manchester Transport in the 1970s.

PVC: The ‘field guide’ version comes with a custom designed PVC jacket, into which the ‘basic’ object is inserted. This robust sleeve is intended to provide weather protection in the damp climes of the north-west. Also inserted in the front inner of this jacket is a paper map plotting all the locations. There will only be 100 copies of the ‘field guide’ version.

Concrete: The 'concrete deluxe' collectors edition comes with a custom formed concrete book cover, (with no PVC jacket) and will be limited to only 20 copies.

Flesh: Meet the author in the flesh and let him personally guide you around a selection of buildings. Richard will avail you of his expert knowledge for just five specially curated tours - oh, and you also get the book (and some additional treats to be announced later).

The Modernist Society

Founded as The Manchester Modernist Society in 2009 by Jack Hale, Eddy Rhead and Maureen Ward, The Modernist Society is a creative project dedicated to celebrating and engaging with twentieth century architecture, through publishing, events, exhibitions and creative collaborations.

Our publishing arm 'The Modernist' was established in 2011, initially publishing as a quarterly printed magazine. The Modernist is now developing into a small press, publishing limited editions about 20th century architecture and design.

The Modernist Society enjoys the the support of its excellent Patrons:

Jonathan Meades: Writer, broadcaster and resident of Le Corbusier's Unite d'Habitation

Johnny Marr: Musician, Mancunian and modernist.

The Modernist Society is a not for profit Community Interest Company

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Spread the word, let others know
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

We thank you!

Vaseem is an artist of pedigree and defined the distinctive visual identity of Warp Records’ hip-hop off shoot, Lex Records, as well as being instrumental in the definition of Manchester’s Skam Records and their aesthetic presence in virtual and printed media. He founded EHQuestionmark and has worked with Richard in one form or another for the best part of fifteen years. This coming together of academic and artist has been made possible by the Modernist Society and we are proud to be able to aid Richard and Vaseem in finally delivering this publication, that is long overdue.The buildings contained in this catalogue have each been visited at least three times by Richard to attain the correct light conditions for his photography. The retrieval of contemporary journal articles in relation to each has meant numerous trips to the RIBA Library in London to access material no longer held in Manchester. The working hours attached to the delivery of the content, let alone the post-editing and design, run into the thousands and in honesty Richard is unable to quantify just what proportion of his life this has consumed. This is a one off print run and will not be reproduced as a second edition, this is your chance to support the continued works of the Modernist Society and to buy into the passion and dedication of one of our most esteemed collaborators.

What We Need & What You Get

We have had a little help from the National Lottery Heritage Fund and a huge input from Richard and Bhatti but in order to get this unique book printed we need to raise a further £7500.
This money will pay for a one off and limited edition print run.
You can help us achieve this by taking up one of our special 'perks'

Cardboard
PVC
Concrete
Flesh

The book is conceived as a field guide and as a collectors object and is available in three formats:
Cardboard: The ‘basic’ object is A6 landscape (26x153x111mm), with 240 pages of vanilla white 150gsm uncoated stock lithographed in black and white, and finished with a silver ink highlight. Each case study building is presented across a single spread with two photographs and a descriptive text. The hardback cover is an uncoated grey recycled 2000micron board which is debossed both front and back, with a spine bound by a white foil-blocked, black canvas tape. The casebound sewn pages can be temporarily bookmarked with an orange ribbon, a colour that references the corporate identity of Greater Manchester Transport in the 1970s.PVC: The ‘field guide’ version comes with a custom designed PVC jacket, into which the ‘basic’ object is inserted. This robust sleeve is intended to provide weather protection in the damp climes of the north-west. Also inserted in the front inner of this jacket is a paper map plotting all the locations. There will only be 100 copies of the ‘field guide’ version.Concrete: The 'concrete deluxe' collectors edition comes with a custom formed concrete book cover, (with no PVC jacket) and will be limited to only 20 copies.
Flesh: Meet the author in the flesh and let him personally guide you around a selection of buildings. Richard will avail you of his expert knowledge for just five specially curated tours - oh, and you also get the book (and some additional treats to be announced later).

The Modernist Society
Founded as The Manchester Modernist Society in 2009 by Jack Hale, Eddy Rhead and Maureen Ward, The Modernist Society is a creative project dedicated to celebrating and engaging with twentieth century architecture, through publishing, events, exhibitions and creative collaborations.
Our publishing arm 'The Modernist' was established in 2011, initially publishing as a quarterly printed magazine. The Modernist is now developing into a small press, publishing limited editions about 20th century architecture and design.
The Modernist Society enjoys the the support of its excellent Patrons:
Jonathan Meades: Writer, broadcaster and resident of Le Corbusier's Unite d'Habitation
Johnny Marr: Musician, Mancunian and modernist.
The Modernist Society is a not for profit Community Interest Company
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Spread the word, let others know
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

We thank you!

story:
We have major news! A sponsor has stepped forward and has pledged to match our indiegogo dollar-for-dollar once we reach our first $1000, up to $1000! So that means once we hit our first $1000, they will match every dollar after that up to $1000!

THAT IS A CHANCE TO RAISE $3000!!!!! Please act now!


WHEN is the festival? September 26th-29th.

Where is the festival? Clarksville, Ohio. Just North of Cincinnati 


What makes Pagan Fires Special?

There are many options when it comes to how you might spend your time, but we hope you consider spending it with us! Pagan Fires is a family friendly camping festival that is organized by a professional staff with over fifty years of combined experience in planning community events. At Pagan Fires, you can expect to see a professional staff that has done all the work so you and your family can enjoy yourselves with a tribe of like-minded people. We welcome well behaved adults, mature kids, and all those who are searching for a community.

The word Pagan encompasses a wide range of spiritual traditions and practices that can’t be seen elsewhere. We don’t always see eye to eye on how to worship or who to worship, but we stand united as group of outliers, facing a world that rarely shares our values. It is more often that society tells us that our differences separate us, but we Pagans know that diversity gives us strength. Perhaps more importantly, that separateness is an illusion.
 

About our Campaign

Each tier comes with one or more raffle tickets that will be used in a drawing at the end of the campaign for some really incredible stuff! By participating in our pre-festival fundraising you not only get what you sign up for but you could also walk away with one of these incredible prizes.

 

Prize 1: Bibliophile Prize Pack – *Signed copies of the following books, shipped to you by October 15. ($280 value) – TWO AVAILABLE

            -Weaving the Liminal by Laura Tempest Zakroff

            -Sigil Witchery by Laura Tempest Zakroff

            -DIY Akashic Wisdom by Jacki Smith

            -Coventry Magic by Jacki Smith

            -Betwixt and Between by Storm Faerywolf

            -Forbidden Mysteries by Storm Faerywolf

            -The Secret Keys of Conjure by Chas Bogan

-The Witch’s Book of Power by Devin Hunter

            - The Witch’s Book of Spirits by Devin Hunter

            -The Witch’s Book of Mysteries by Devin Hunter

 

Prize 2: Golden Ticket - ALL Ever-Green Content on the Mystic Dream Academy unlocked for TWO YEARS! (estimated value $1,200.) This includes Black Rose Witchcraft, Modern Conjure, The Witch Power Masterclass, and all upcoming content released over the next year. -ONE AVAILABLE

 

Prize 3: Modern Conjure Gift Box – One of all twenty-one Modern Conjure Condition Oils ($200 value) -TWO AVAILABLE

 

Prize 4: LIMITED EDITION Modern Witch style Wooden Witch Power Box Set, including signed copies of The Witch’s Book of Power, The Witch’s Book of Spirits, and The Witch’s Book of Mysteries. ($100 value) – TWO AVAILABLE

 

Prize 5: Pagan Fires Prize Pack: ADMISSION FOR TWO ADULTS at Pagan Fires 2020. ($500 Value) -ONE AVAILABLE

 

Prize 6: Prism Prize Pack – The latest Two CD’s from Frenchy & The Punk and Nathaniel Johnstone. ($100 Value) – ONE AVAILABLE

 

Prize 7: The Witch Power Master Class ADMIT ONE ($250 Value) – THREE AVAILABLE

 

Prize 8: Black Rose Witchcraft Online Course ADMIT ONE ($250 value) – TWO AVAILABLE

 

Prize 9: A digital date with Devin Hunter. One hour on skype or zoom with Devin Hunter to pick his brain about anything. -ONE AVAILABLE

 

Prize 10: Signed Event Poster - FIVE AVAILABLE

 

Campaign Tiers

 

Tier One: $5.00 – Blessed Be!

 A Thank you and ONE raffle ticket for the end of campaign drawing.

 

Tier Two: $25.00 – Merry Meet!

Our gratitude, THREE raffle tickets for end of campaign drawing and a song download from Nathaniel Johnstone’s new album!

 

Tier Three: $50.00- Be Here Now!

A big THANK YOU from the bottom of our hearts, SEVEN raffle tickets for the of campaign drawing, a song download from Nathaniel Johnstone’s new album, a video download of Keynote speech by Laura Tempest Zakroff, a postcard from Pagan Fires, and your name mentioned in the program!

 

Tier Four: $100- So Must it Be!

Everything from the previous tier PLUS THREE more raffle tickets (10 total), a signed limited-edition 8" x10" print of “Prism” by Laura Tempest Zakroff, and a half ounce bottle of limited-edition Prism Ritual oil from Violet Flame Gifts. 

 

Tier Five: $250- High Magic’s Aid

Everything from the previous tier PLUS THREE more raffle tickets (13 total), a festival poster signed by all of the presenters and musicians, and a crossroads crystal grid set (Featuring Labradorite, Amethyst and Quartz) empowered during the Hecate at the Crossroads ritual on Friday night. 

 

Tier Six: $500- The Supreme

Everything from the previous tier PLUS SEVEN more raffle tickets (20 total), the entire Black Rose Witchcraft course from the Mystic Dream Academy for you and a friend!


More about Pagan Fires...

E Pluribus Unum, From Many One.

For our debut year we have chosen PRISM: Many Colors, One Lightas our theme and will be focusing on the strength found in our community through its embrace of diversity. We will be highlighting the many traditions, organizations, and persons that make up the local Pagan and Pagan Fires communities and will work with art as metaphor for personal and communal growth. Our programming is specifically geared towards promoting the fundamental elements of Paganism such as meditation, earth stewardship, and ancestor worship all within a container of respect, compassion, and responsibility.

 

Event Staff

Devin Hunter – Organizer/ Onsite Management

Heather Killen– Organizer/ Onsite Operations

Tiffany Ware – Operations & Guest Services

Soolah Hoops – Head of Children’s Programing

Storm Faerywolf –Talent Liaison & Registration Coordinator

Chas Bogan – Vendor Liaison & Silent Auction Coordinator

Jenn A Lady– Green Room Coordinator

Bone – Head of Security

Darwin RedSky – Dining Hall Coordinator

All Sabbat Entertainment events donate a portion of ticket sales to a charity that supports the vision of the festival community. This year we have chosen to donate funds to The Nature Conservancy of Ohio. While we have no affiliation with them, we believe their work to be crucial to the ecological health of Ohio’s waterways and wetlands. On the last day a check will be presented on behalf of the Pagan Fires community.

 

How You Can Help

Help us raise $4,444 in startup capital to assist in the production of Pagan Fires, the all new outdoor pagan festival. Festivals are pricey to put on and this is a new one! We need help getting the ball rolling and are seeking $4,444 USD to help us make our new event something truly magical. We are having the festival one way or the other, but sure could use some assistance getting the ball rolling.
